title: Effects of Donepezil HCL on Task-Activated fMRI Brain Activation in Healthy Older Adults at Genetic Risk for Alzheimer's Disease
description_brief: This study examines the sensitivity of functional MRI to detect brain changes caused by donepezil HCL (a cholinesterase inhibitor) in healthy older adults at genetic risk for Alzheimer's Disease.
description_detailed: This 24-week study will examine the sensitivity of functional MRI to detect brain changes caused by donepezil HCL (a cholinesterase inhibitor) in healthy older adults at genetic risk for Alzheimer's Disease. Participants with a family history of Alzheimer's Disease will be eligible for this study. Participants without a family history of AD will also be enrolled to serve as a control group.

groups.title: Donepezil HCL
groups.description:
Participants will receive 5mg of donepezil HCL for 4 weeks and then 10mg of donepezil HCL for 20 weeks.

donepezil HCL

groups.title: Placebo
groups.description:
Participants will receive placebo for 24 weeks.

Placebo

groups.title: Control Group
groups.description: Participants without a family history of AD will undergo the study evaluations but will not receive any study drug

dropWithdraws.type: Not analyzed due to anatomical abnormalities

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in BOLD Response From Baseline to 24 Weeks During Functional Magnetic Resonance Imaging - Left Posterior Cingulate BOLD Signal at 24 Weeks, Adjusting for Baseline Left Posterior Cingulate BOLD
outcomeMeasures.description: Changes from baseline to 24 weeks follow-up fMRI - Left posterior cingulate BOLD signal at 24 weeks, adjusting for baseline left posterior cingulate BOLD signal.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Please note that the fMRI result of one subject was collected but could not be processed due to data quality issues. Hence, only 21 subjects in Donepezil HCL arm were analyzed.

outcomeMeasures.title: Neuropsychological Testing Scores - Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT) Sum of Trials (1-5) at 24 Weeks, Adjusted for Baseline RAVLT Score
outcomeMeasures.description: Rey Auditory Verbal Learning Test (RAVLT) (Sum of Trials 1-5) , adjusting for baseline RAVLT (Sum of Trials 1-5) score. The RAVLT total score has a minimum of 0 and a maximum of 75 correct items (15 per trial x 5 trials). A higher score means better outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Brief Visuospatial Memory Test (BVMT) Learning Scores at 24 Weeks, Adjusted for Baseline BVMT Learning Scores
outcomeMeasures.description: Brief Visuospatial Memory Test (BVMT) learning scores at 24 weeks, adjusted for baseline BVMT learning scores. The BVMT-R total scare has a minimum of 0 and a maximum of 36 correct items (12 per trial x 3 trials). A higher score means better outcomes.

outcomeMeasures.title: Processing Speed Test (PST) at 24 Weeks, Adjusted for Baseline PST Scores
outcomeMeasures.description: Processing speed test (PST) at 24 weeks, adjusting for baseline PST scores. The PST has a minimum of 0 and no upper limit/maximum since it is the number of correct items in 2 minutes. A higher score means better outcome.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: Please note only those participants who had complete PST data were included in the analysis, which are 12 participants in Donepezil HCL group, 15 participants in Placebo group, and 22 participants in Control group.

explanation_target: Reason: The trial tests donepezil HCl, a centrally acting acetylcholinesterase (cholinesterase) inhibitor, to detect fMRI changes caused by the drug in cognitively healthy older adults at genetic risk for Alzheimer’s. Donepezil is used to improve cognition symptomatically in AD rather than to modify underlying AD pathology. citeturn0search4turn0search9

Act: Key extracted details — intervention: donepezil HCl (Aricept); drug type: a small-molecule, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor (cholinesterase inhibitor) that increases synaptic acetylcholine and is indicated for symptomatic treatment of Alzheimer’s dementia. Because the intended effect in this study is to detect brain activation changes (cognitive/functional effects) rather than to target amyloid or tau pathology, it matches the cognitive-enhancer category. citeturn0search3turn0search5

Reflect: Classification check — the four category definitions: (1) disease-targeted biologic (biologics vs small molecules) — NOT applicable; (2) disease-targeted small molecule (small molecules that target AD pathology like amyloid/tau) — donepezil does not target amyloid/tau; (3) cognitive enhancer — fits: symptomatic cholinergic enhancement to improve/alter cognitive-related brain activation; (4) neuropsychiatric symptom improvement — not the primary aim here. Therefore final category: cognitive enhancer. citeturn0search8

Web search results (supporting citations): 1) Donepezil is a reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor developed for symptomatic treatment of AD (reviews/PubMed). citeturn0search4turn0search1 2) Aricept (donepezil HCl) FDA labeling / prescribing information confirms indication for symptomatic treatment of Alzheimer dementia and dosing forms. citeturn0search5 3) Manufacturer information (Pfizer/Eisai) describing Aricept (donepezil HCl) and noting it provides symptomatic benefits but is not a cure / disease-modifying therapy. citeturn0search2 4) Drug databases and summaries classify donepezil as a small-molecule cholinesterase inhibitor and summarize mechanism (increases acetylcholine via AChE inhibition). citeturn0search3turn0search9
explanation_agent: Reason: The intervention is donepezil HCl (Aricept), a centrally acting, reversible acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases synaptic acetylcholine and thereby enhances cholinergic neurotransmission—i.e., it modulates a neurotransmitter system rather than targeting amyloid, tau, ApoE, inflammation, etc. citeturn0search4turn0search2

Act: Extracted details — drug: donepezil HCl (Aricept); mechanism: reversible acetylcholinesterase (AChE) inhibition leading to increased acetylcholine and enhanced cholinergic signaling; clinical role: symptomatic cognitive enhancement in AD rather than disease modification. These attributes map to CADRO category D) Neurotransmitter Receptors (modulation of neurotransmitter systems/cognition). citeturn0search4turn0search8

Reflect: Confirmation — donepezil’s primary pharmacology and FDA indication support classification under neurotransmitter modulation (cholinergic system). The trial’s aim (detecting task-activated fMRI changes/cognitive-enhancer effects in at-risk but cognitively healthy older adults) is consistent with a symptomatic cognitive-enhancement approach rather than a pathology-modifying one, so D) Neurotransmitter Receptors is the most specific CADRO fit (not R) Multi-target or T) Other). citeturn0search9turn0search5

Web search results used (supporting sources): 1) StatPearls: Donepezil mechanism — reversible centrally acting AChE inhibitor. citeturn0search4 2) Aricept (donepezil) prescribing information / package insert (drug description, indications). citeturn0search2 3) PubMed review summaries describing donepezil’s symptomatic benefit and mechanism. citeturn0search8 4) Clinical studies and summaries showing cognitive/symptomatic effects in AD. citeturn0search9 5) Drug database summary (donepezil as small-molecule AChE inhibitor, symptomatic treatment). citeturn0search5
